user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_extended_uname_copy_z:
```c
static ssize_t
get_rq_extended_uname_copy_z (const char *uname_ext, size_t uname_ext_len,
                              char *buf, size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t r;
  size_t w;
  if ((size_t) SSIZE_MAX < uname_ext_len)
    return -1; /* Too long input string */

  if (MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_MIN_LEN > uname_ext_len)
    return -1; /* Required prefix is missing */

  if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (uname_ext, MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX,
                                       MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                         MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX)))
    return -1; /* Only UTF-8 is supported, as it is implied by RFC 7616 */

  r = MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX);
  /* Skip language tag */
  while (r < uname_ext_len && '\'' != uname_ext[r])
  {
    const char chr = uname_ext[r];
    if ((' ' == chr) || ('\t' == chr) || ('\"' == chr) || (',' == chr) ||
        (';' == chr) )
      return -1; /* Wrong char in language tag */
    r++;
  }
  if (r >= uname_ext_len)
    return -1; /* The end of the language tag was not found */
  r++; /* Advance to the next char */

  w = MHD_str_pct_decode_strict_n_ (uname_ext + r, uname_ext_len - r,
                                    buf, buf_size);
  if ((0 == w) && (0 != uname_ext_len - r))
    return -1; /* Broken percent encoding */
  buf[w] = 0; /* Zero terminate the result */
  mhd_assert (SSIZE_MAX > w);
  return (ssize_t) w;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (! MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (uname_ext, MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX,
                                       MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ ( \
                                         MHD_DAUTH_EXT_PARAM_PREFIX)))
    return -1; /* Only UTF-8 is supported, as it is implied by RFC 7616 */
explanation:
The rest of the function's operations are protected by explicit bounds checks and do not appear to risk accesses beyond object bounds:
- The initial check ((size_t) SSIZE_MAX < uname_ext_len) prevents uname_ext_len from exceeding SSIZE_MAX so subsequent conversions to ssize_t are safe.
- The while loop that inspects uname_ext[r] is guarded by the condition r < uname_ext_len, preventing out-of-range reads while scanning the language tag.
- After the loop there is a check if (r >= uname_ext_len) return -1; so any use of r after that is safe (and r++ is handled so that uname_ext + r with length uname_ext_len - r is well-defined, possibly zero-length).
- mhd_assert(SSIZE_MAX > w) documents an expectation about w's range (though it is not a runtime guard, it is not a source of additional out-of-bounds access by itself).

The only fragments requiring further investigation relative to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 are the calls to the string/percent-decode helper functions (which may read from uname_ext without being given uname_ext_len) and the explicit termination write buf[w] = 0 (which may write past buf if the decoder returns a length equal to buf_size or if buf_size == 0). Other reads/writes in the function are covered by the shown bounds checks.
